trial_identification.studytitle: Effects of Exercise Training on Arterial Stiffness in Haemodialysis Patients
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Effects of aerobic exercise training on arterial stiffness in end-stage renal disease patients on maintenance haemodialysis

interventions.interventions: 6 months Intradialytic exercise training (3 times per week for up to 45mins) on leg-cycle Monark Rehab Trainer 881 at Borg's (6-20) rating of perceived exertion scale of 12-13. 6months outside-dialysis walking program (3 times per week for up to 45 minutes) at Borg's (6-20) rating of perceived exertion scale of 12-13.
interventions.comparator: The control is 6 months usual care of haemodialysis treatment with no exercise training

primaryOutcome.outcome: Arterial stiffness measured by augmentation and pulsewave velocity
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, 3- and 6- months after commencement of intervention

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Self-reported health and physical activity levels using the SF-36 survey and Active Australia Questionnaire respectively
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, 3- and 6 months after commencement of intervention

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Physical function as measured by 6-minute walk test, hand grip strength, and timed-get up and go test
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, 3- and 6- months after commencement of intervention

eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Individuals with known unstable angina, or lower limb(s) amputation, or already participate in high amounts of physical activity

trial_design.concealment: Participants from renal units are approached to participate in the study. A full informed consent process of four weeks was performed before subjects give written consent to participate in the study. The person consenting the patient is not aware of the group the patient will be allocated to. The allocation is performed off-site by a third party using a randomly generated sequence created by a computer software.
trial_design.sequence: Randomly generated sequence created by a computer software

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Launceston General Hospital Charles St Launceston Tasmania 7250

secondarysponsor.sponsoraddress: School of Human Life Sciences, Newham Tasmania

othercollaborator.othercollaboratoraddress: School of Human Movement Studies St. Lucia Queensland

ethicsAndSummary.publication: ACSM (New Orleans, Apr 2007) - Poster Comparison of supervised exercise training and non-supervised exercise training on arterial stiffness, physical function and self-reported quality of life. ACSMS (Adelaide, 13-16 Oct 2007) - Podium Comparison of supervised exercise training and non-supervised exercise training on arterial stiffness, physical function and self-reported quality of life. APCESS (Hiroshima, 6-8 Dec 2007) - Poster Comparison of supervised exercise training and non-supervised exercise training on arterial stiffness, physical function and self-reported quality of life. Medical Research Week (Launceston General Hospital, Sep 2006) - Oral The Effects of Exercise Training on Arterial Stiffness, Physical Function and Quality of Life in Haemodialysis Patients: The PEDAL Study. AAESS Conference (Mar 2008)-oral Effects of Exercise Training on Arterial Stiffness, Physical Function and Self-reported Health in Haemodialysis Patients
